results.title: Admission impossible
results.creator_credit: Alec Morgan, Chris Oliver and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The very first Act passed by Australia’s first parliament was a law to exclude non-white races from Australia. “Admission impossible” is the true story of the behind-the-scenes political forces and propaganda that created the infamous White Australia Policy which was enforced until 1972. Eyewitness accounts and recently discovered confidential documents reveal how immigration officers carried out racial selectivity to discriminate against Asians, Jews and non-European applicants. The last part of the program discusses the impact the Vietnam War had on the reversal of this policy.

results.title: La Stupenda: a portrait of Dame Joan Sutherland
results.creator_credit: Derek Bailey, Brian Adams and Landseer Film and Television Productions
results.brief_description: A celebration of the life and career of Australia’s most famous opera star, Dame Joan Sutherland, culminating in her farewell performances in Sydney and London in 1990. Sutherland’s career spanned more than forty years. “La Stupenda” provides an overview of the highlights of her career.

results.title: Wharfies: A History of the Waterside Worker's Federation
results.brief_description: Wharfies traces the history of the Australian Waterside Workers Federation from its foundation in 1902, under Billy Hughes, to the present day. Made in the tradition of the Waterside Workers Film Unit of the 1950s, “Wharfies” covers important historical events including industrial milestones, political crises and the stories of the men themselves. This film is pieced together through dramatised sequences, interviews with veteran wharfies and rare archival footage. Cartoons, news clippings and old photographs all help to tell the story.

results.title: Soldier settlers
results.brief_description: Portrays the progress made since 1945 in the establishment of ex-servicemen from World War II on Victorian land. The division of large estates, the development of existing pastures, the clearing of scrub country and the construction of irrigation channels are seen on representative farms throughout the state. Fruit growing, the dried fruit industry, wheat cultivation and sheep raising, plus dry and irrigated dairying are shown, in addition to the single-unit farm system.

results.title: After hours
results.creator_credit: Jane Campion, Australian Film Commission, Women's Film Unit and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Dramatized situation of an office worker who alleges sexual abuse when asked to stay back late to finish some typing. She loses her job as a result of her claims. Both her fellow workers and boyfriend fail to understand her situation, somehow blaming her for what happened. The investigator for the case finds difficulty in obtaining evidence from people associated with the manager. Cast: Danielle Pearse, Don Reid, Anna-Maria Monticelli, Russell Newman.

results.title: High and wild
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Kestrel Films & Video (Australia)
results.brief_description: High and Wild is the latest video from the Wilderness Society’s ongoing education program. It traces the journey of eight students and their teacher from Melbourne’s Kingswood College on what, for most, was their first wilderness experience. Shot on location in Victoria’s Wonnangatta-Moroka National Park “High and Wild” captures the students’ experience as they explore a variety of issues surrounding wilderness - such as alpine grazing logging, flora/fauna protection, outdoor recreation, Aboriginal and World Heritage values.

results.title: Wild about wilderness
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Kestrel Films & Video (Australia)
results.brief_description: Deborah Conway hosts this video which attempts to define wilderness areas that are left. All wilderness areas shown are from New South Wales. Finishes with the sobering thought that what we don’t save now is lost for ever.

results.title: We call it paradise
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence
results.brief_description: Niree Creed presents this portrait of Garden Island, 6 km. south of Perth and the effect the construction of HMAS Stirling, a naval base, has had on the island and on the town of Rockingham. The construction of the base caused some controversy as squatters, who had lived there for many years, were removed in the process. This film, produced by Defence Public Relations emphasises the benefits the base has brought to the local community.

results.title: Buildings and Bushfires-Improving the Chances of Survival
results.creator_credit: University of Melbourne and Television Production Unit
results.brief_description: Bushfires are an inevitable hazard in Australia. The tranquillity of the bush belies its potential to burn fiercely when conditions are suitable. This program shows how bushfires start fires in buildings, how embers, radiation and flame, aided by wind cause ignition and destruction of buildings; that embers are the most important means of ignition; that well-designed buildings have a very good chance of survival; and that such buildings will provide a safer place of refuge for people in bushfires.
